subject: Re: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... The main issue is that a class with a large number of private methods is probably doing too much work. A significant amount of that work could be pushed
messageBody:
David wrote:

>Message: 12
> Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 10:30:18 +0200
> From: David <novotique@...>
>Subject: Re: How to test private methods in a class.
>
>Hi,
>
>I don't agree with this. Imagine that you have class with one point of entry
>for the client i.e. one public method. You can't change the access modifier
>of your method just to test it. Wrapping your private method in a public
>method is just the same as changing the access modifier. It is will
>documented and it works to use java reflection.
>
>
>
The main issue is that a class with a large number of private methods is
probably doing too much work. A significant amount of that work could be
pushed off to helper classes. This will often (always, in my experience)
result in a better and simpler design that, _as a side effect_, is more
testable. I also end up with less duplication in the code base.

I normally make these helper classes package-private until I can promote
them to more generally used classes; some get this status, but most
wouldn't.

Robert.
